A 2  2  2 ANOVA examining the effect of condition (0 or 54), crawling (crawler or non-crawler), and gender (female or male) as between-participants variables on the preference score for mirror objects revealed no significant main effect of gender or any interactions involving gender (all Fs < 1.13, all ps > .05).

Prior assumption checks of parametric testing showed that the preference score for mirror objects was normally distributed for all groups according to Shapiro-Wilk (missing p-value due to small group size of n = 2 only for female infants presented with the R-object during habituation in the test stimulus order of mirror object first, all other ps > .503), and that the variances were equal according to Levene’s test (p = .176). The analysis revealed no main effects of gender, habituation object, or order of test stimulus presentation, nor any interactions (all Fs < 2.69, all ps > .10); thus, we collapsed across these factors to simplify the following main analysis.
Note that no significant interactions between orientation outcome and sex (F(1,13) 􏰂 1), event order (F(1,13) 􏰂 1), starting orientation (F(1,13) 􏰂 1), or test order (F(1,16) 􏰂 1) were found.
No significant interactions of orientation with sex (F(1,19) 􏰂 1), event order (F(1,19) 􏰂 1), starting orientation (F(1,19) 􏰂 1), or test order (F(1,19) 􏰂 1) were found.
There was no significant interactions of orientation with age (F(1,17) 􏰂 1), sex (F(1,17) 􏰂 1), event order (F(1,17) 􏰂 1), starting orientation (F(1,17) 􏰂 1), or test order (F(1,17) 􏰂 1).
There were no significant interactions of orientation with sex (F(1,17) 􏰂 1), starting orientation (F(1,17) = 2.719, P 􏰂 0.11), or test order (F(1,17) 􏰂 1).

In the overall analysis, there were no significant interactions between orientation outcome and sex (F(1,16) 􏰂 1), event order (F(1,16) 􏰂 1), starting orientation (F(1,16) 􏰂 1), or test order (F(1,16) 􏰂 1).
There were no significant interactions of orientation with sex (F(1,16) 􏰂 1), event order (F(1,16) 􏰂 1), start- ing orientation (F(1,16) 􏰂 1), or test order (F(1,16) 􏰂 1)

A preliminary ANOVA revealed no significant differences between girls and boys regarding their preference scores, F(1, 22) = 1.09,

To compare the performance of girls and boys on this task, we conducted a two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the between-subjects variables of sex and side of mirror stream on the first trial. The dependent variable was the proportion of looking time to the mirror stream. This analysis revealed a significant main effect of sex, F(1,52) = 4.16, p = 0.046 (η 2 p = 0.07), but no other main effect (p > 0.2) or interaction (p > 0.4).
